title: 107_hr5596
content: Exemption for certain state and local political committees from notification requirements. Exemption from notification requirements for state and local political committees under section 527(i) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include political committees of state or local candidates and state or local committees of political parties. The amendments will take effect as if included in Public Law 106-230. Exemption for state and local political committees from reporting requirements. The amendment exempts qualified State or local political organizations from certain reporting requirements under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendment exempts qualified State or local political organizations from specific reporting requirements under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It defines a qualified State or local political organization as one whose exempt functions solely aim to influence the selection, nomination, election, or appointment of individuals to State or local public offices. The amendment exempts qualified State or local political organizations from reporting requirements if their functions solely aim to influence the selection of individuals to public offices. The amendment requires disclosure of information on expenditures, contributions, and individuals involved in political organizations. The organization is not required to report certain information if it is already made public by the agency it was filed with and available for inspection by the organization. State law differences are disregarded for meeting reporting requirements. An organization is not considered to fail meeting reporting requirements solely due to certain state law differences, such as minor discrepancies in required reporting amounts or the need to disclose specific information. The employer of a person who contributes to the organization. The organization must disclose the occupation of contributors, recipients of expenditures, purpose of expenditures, contribution dates, and expenditure dates. An organization will not lose its status as a qualified State or local political organization for minor errors in meeting reporting and inspection requirements, as long as the errors are promptly corrected. The term 'qualified State or local political organization' does not include organizations where a federal candidate or office holder controls or participates in its direction, or solicits contributions, unless approved by the Secretary. The amendments made by this section shall take effect for organizations where a federal candidate or office holder controls, solicits contributions, or directs disbursements. The amendments made by this section shall take effect for organizations where a federal candidate or office holder controls, solicits contributions, or directs disbursements, including the organization's officers, directors, agents, or employees. The effective date of these amendments is as if included in Public Law 106-230. SEC. 3. EXEMPTION FROM ANNUAL RETURN REQUIREMENTS. Income Tax Returns Required Only for Political Organization. Taxable Income paragraph of the Internal Revenue Code amended to remove certain requirements. Income Tax Returns Not Subject to Disclosure. Amendments made to disclosure and public inspection sections of the Code. Section 6104 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to remove disclosure requirements for certain annual information returns. Public inspection rules for annual returns are also updated. Section 6033 is amended regarding returns required by political organizations. Section 6033 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to update disclosure requirements for political organizations with gross receipts of $25,000 or more. For qualified State or local political organizations, the threshold is increased to $100,000. The Internal Revenue Code is updated to require political organizations with gross receipts of $25,000 or more to file annual returns. For qualified State or local political organizations, the threshold is raised to $100,000. The Internal Revenue Code now mandates political organizations with gross receipts of $25,000 or more to file annual returns. Exceptions apply for State or local political committees. Exceptions from filing annual returns apply to certain political organizations, including State or local political committees, caucuses, authorized committees of candidates for Federal office, and national committees of political parties. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 outlines exceptions from filing annual returns for certain political organizations, including national committees of political parties, House or Senate campaign committees, and political committees required to report under the Act. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 exempts certain political organizations from filing annual returns, including national committees of political parties, House or Senate campaign committees, and political committees required to report under the Act. The Secretary has the discretion to waive the filing requirement for organizations if it is deemed unnecessary for efficient tax administration. The Secretary can waive the filing requirement for certain political organizations if it is not necessary for tax administration. The amendments made by this section will be effective as if included in Public Law 106-230. SEC. 4. NOTIFICATION OF INTERACTION OF REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Federal Election Commission, shall publicize the effect of the amendments made by this Act and the interaction of requirements to file notifications or reports under section 527 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and reports under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Information provided shall be included in any form, instruction, notice, or guidance issued to the public regarding reporting requirements of political organizations. The Secretary of the Treasury and the Federal Election Commission will provide information on reporting requirements for political organizations under the Internal Revenue Code and the Federal Election Campaign Act. This information will be included in public guidance issued by the Secretary of the Treasury or the Federal Election Commission. SEC. 5. WAIVER OF FILING AMOUNTS. The Secretary may waive tax assessed on an organization for failure to comply with requirements, effective after June 30, 2000. SEC. 6. MODIFICATIONS TO SECTION 527 ORGANIZATION DISCLOSURE PROVISIONS. (a) Unsegregated Funds Not To Avoid Tax.--Paragraph (4) of section 527(i) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include exempt function income as any amount described in subsection (c)(3), whether segregated or not. (b) Procedures for Assessment and Collection of Amounts.--Paragraph (1) of section 527(j) is amended to include required disclosure of expenditures and contributions. (c) Procedures for Assessment and Collection of Amounts.--Section 527(j) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include that the amount imposed will be assessed and collected similar to penalties under section 6652(c). Additionally, duplicate written filings are no longer required under section 527(i)(1), only electronic submissions are necessary. Application of the fraud penalty is covered under section 7207. (e) Contents and Filing of Report.-- Section 527(j)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code specifies the contents required for filing reports. The contents required for filing reports under section 527(j)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code are amended to include additional details such as amount, date, and purpose. Electronic filing is also addressed in the amendment. The amendment includes electronic filing requirements for organizations with contributions or expenditures exceeding $50,000 in a calendar year. The amendment mandates electronic filing for organizations with contributions or expenditures over $50,000 in a calendar year. The Secretary must make notices and reports available for public inspection on the Internet within 48 hours of filing. The Secretary is required to make notices and reports available for public inspection on the Internet within 48 hours of filing. The database must be searchable by names, states, zip codes, custodians of records, directors, and general purposes of the organizations. The database of notices and reports must include information on organizations, related entities, contributors, employers of contributors, recipients of expenditures, contribution and expenditure ranges, and time periods. It should be downloadable for public access. It should be downloadable for public access. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include specifying ranges of contributions and expenditures, time periods of notices and reports, and details on claiming exemptions from certain requirements. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include specifying ranges of contributions and expenditures, time periods of notices and reports, and details on claiming exemptions from certain requirements. The timing of notice in case of a material change is also addressed in the amendments. The Internal Revenue Code amendments address timeframes for giving notice of material changes in required information, specifying a 30-day deadline for such notifications. Failure to comply with these notice requirements may have consequences as outlined in the Code. The Internal Revenue Code amendments require notice of material changes within 30 days to avoid consequences outlined in the Code. Effective Dates: The amendments made by subsections (a) and (b) apply to failures occurring after the enactment of this Act. The amendments made by subsection (c) take effect as if included in Public Law 106-230. The amendment made by subsection (d) applies to reports and notices filed after the enactment of this Act. The amendments made by subsections (e)(1) and (f) apply to reports and notices required to be filed more than 30 days after the enactment of this Act. The amendments made by subsections (e)(2) and (e)(3) apply to reports required to be filed on or after June 30, 2003. The amendments made by subsection (g) of the Act apply to material changes on or after the enactment date, with a transition rule for changes within 30 days of enactment. The transition rule for material changes within 30 days of the enactment of the Act states that a notice under section 527(i) of the Internal Revenue Code is not required to be filed before 30 days after the material change or 45 days after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 7. EFFECT OF AMENDMENTS ON EXISTING DISCLOSURES. Notices, reports, or returns filed with the Secretary of the Treasury before the enactment of the amendments shall remain subject to disclosure provisions of section 6104 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
